description: A psSiteRouter trap signifies that the site router
attached to the device has changed to a state of less
readiness. The psAlarmSiteRouterStatus variable included with
this trap provides more information.
Status of the site router. A status of gone(2) means that PacketShaper
has stopped getting arp replies from the router. error-inside(3)
means that it most recently got a reply, but from the inside. none(4)
means that no site router was configured.
variables.name: PACKETEER-MIB::psAlarmSiteRouterStatus

description: A psPowerSystemOne trap signifies that the first power
supply of the device has failed.
A psSitePowerSystemTwo trap signifies that
the second power supply of the device has failed.
A psFanOne trap signifies that the first fan
of the device has failed.
A psAlarmFanTwo trap signifies that second fan
of the device has failed.
A psAlarmCfgFile trap signifies that the configuration
file of the device has been corrupted, or otherwise changed
to a state of less readiness. This trap is obsolete and
should not be used.
A psAlarmUserEvent trap signifies that a user event, which has
been registered by the user, has occurred. The associated variables
give more information on the event.
objects.test: $SNMPTRAPCMD PACKETEER-MIB::psAlarmUserEvent PACKETEER-MIB::userEventTrapName s EXAMPLE PACKETEER-MIB::userEventTrapExpression s EXAMPLE PACKETEER-MIB::userEventTrapVariable s EXAMPLE PACKETEER-MIB::userEventTrapElementType i 1 PACKETEER-MIB::userEventTrapRegid i 9999 PACKETEER-MIB::userEventTrapDate s EXAMPLEE PACKETEER-MIB::userEventTrapValue i 9999 PACKETEER-MIB::userEventTrapTarget s EXAMPLE PACKETEER-MIB::userEventTrapThreshold i 9999 PACKETEER-MIB::userEventTrapRearm i 9999 PACKETEER-MIB::userEventTrapDayCount i 9999 PACKETEER-MIB::userEventTrapDayLimit i 9999

description: The name of the user event which has occurred.
variables.name: PACKETEER-MIB::userEventTrapName

description: The expression defining this user event.
variables.name: PACKETEER-MIB::userEventTrapExpression

description: The name of the Measurement Engine variable which is
tested in this user event.
variables.name: PACKETEER-MIB::userEventTrapVariable

description: The type of element which is tested in this user event.
variables.name: PACKETEER-MIB::userEventTrapElementType

description: The registration of this user event.
variables.name: PACKETEER-MIB::userEventTrapRegid

description: The time the event occurred.
variables.name: PACKETEER-MIB::userEventTrapDate

description: The value of userEventTrapVariable which triggered the event.
variables.name: PACKETEER-MIB::userEventTrapValue

description: The name of the link, class, or partition
as given in userEventTrapElementType, which is
the target of this event regiatration.
variables.name: PACKETEER-MIB::userEventTrapTarget

description: The threshold value which triggers this event.
See the value of userEventTrapExpression
for the signedness with respect to the threshold (<, >, etc.)
variables.name: PACKETEER-MIB::userEventTrapThreshold

description: The rearm value which must be hit after an occurrence
of this event in order to rearm it.
See the value of userEventTrapExpression
for the signedness with respect to the threshold (<, >, etc.)
variables.name: PACKETEER-MIB::userEventTrapRearm

description: The number of times this event has occurred on this
day (as counted from midnight to midnight, local time).
If this value is greater than or equal to userEventTrapDayLimit
and that value is non-zero, then no more instances of this
event will be reported until the next day.
variables.name: PACKETEER-MIB::userEventTrapDayCount

description: The maximum number of times this event is allowed to occur per
day (as counted from midnight to midnight, local time)
as configured by the user. A value of zero denotes no limit.
variables.name: PACKETEER-MIB::userEventTrapDayLimit

description: A psAlarmMeasurementEngine trap signifies that the Measurement
Engine has changed to a state of less readiness, or failed on
startup.
The current status of the Measurement Engine. The values
enumerated above correspond to those shown in the command
line 'me show' command.
(1) initially starting
(2) starting
(3) running
(4) error on volume
(5) disabled
(6) wait to start
(7) suspended
(8) backing up data
(9) restoring data
variables.name: PACKETEER-MIB::psAlarmMeasurementEngineStatus

description: A psAlarmStandby trap signifies that the standby
status of the device has changed to a state of less
readiness. The psAlarmStandbyStatus variable included with
this trap provides more information.
Status of the standby feature. A status of not-configured(1) means that
standby is not configured for this PacketShaper. active(2) means hot standby is
processing traffic according to its shaping mode. passive(3) means hot standby
is not processing traffic but is monitoring the active partner of the paired
PacketShapers. down(4) means hot standby has declared itself ineligible for
active mode due to a self-detected fault. direct(5) means standby direct is
processing and copying traffic to its partner. disconnected(6) means standby
direct is non-functional since it cannot reach its partner. leak(7) means the
Packetshaper has detected a loop in the network and so has disabled the stanby
direct functionality and is only processing traffic flowing through it. disable(8)
means that the standby direct feature has been disabled and is non-functional.
variables.name: PACKETEER-MIB::psAlarmStandbyStatus

description: A psFeatureHighAvDeviceFailed trap signifies that an interface
or router we are tracking has gone down. If it is an interface that
went down, the bindings will show the corresponding router and the
name of the interface which went down. The name will be specified
as 'unknown' if we could not resolve the interface name. But if it
is the router that went down, the interface name will not be specified.
objects.test: $SNMPTRAPCMD PACKETEER-MIB::psFeatureHighAvDeviceDown PACKETEER-MIB::psFeatureHighAvDeviceDownStatus i 1 PACKETEER-MIB::psFeatureHighAvDeviceDownRouter s EXAMPLE PACKETEER-MIB::psFeatureHighAvDeviceDownInterface s EXAMPLE

description: The operational status of the interface of the router
we are polling.
(1) UP
(2) DOWN.
variables.name: PACKETEER-MIB::psFeatureHighAvDeviceDownStatus

description: The name of a router that has gone down
or the name of the router whose one of the
interfaces has gone down.
variables.name: PACKETEER-MIB::psFeatureHighAvDeviceDownRouter

description: The name of the interface that has gone down. The name
will be specified as 'unknown' in the cases where we
could not resolve the interface name. The interface
name will have a value of NULL or zero-length value
if the router goes down.
variables.name: PACKETEER-MIB::psFeatureHighAvDeviceDownInterface

description: A psAlarmAgentEvent trap signifies that an agent event, which has
been triggered by the user, has occurred. The associated variables
give more information on the event.
objects.test: $SNMPTRAPCMD PACKETEER-MIB::psAlarmAgentEvent PACKETEER-MIB::agentEventTrapName s EXAMPLE PACKETEER-MIB::agentEventTrapDate s EXAMPLEE PACKETEER-MIB::agentEventTrapType i 0 PACKETEER-MIB::agentEventTrapDescription s EXAMPLE

description: The name of the agent instance which has fired the event.
variables.name: PACKETEER-MIB::agentEventTrapName

description: The time the event occurred.
variables.name: PACKETEER-MIB::agentEventTrapDate

description: The type of event that occurred, 0 = GREEN, 1 = RED, 2 = YELLOW, 3 = BLUE.
variables.name: PACKETEER-MIB::agentEventTrapType

description: A description of the event that has occurred.
variables.name: PACKETEER-MIB::agentEventTrapDescription

description: A psAlarmFanThree trap signifies that 3rd fan
of the device has failed.
A psAlarmFanFour trap signifies that 4th fan
of the device has failed.
